body:
# The Core Suite

The Core suite of libraries is an industrial strength alternative to OCaml's standard library that was developed by [Jane Street](http://janestreet.com), the largest industrial user of OCaml.

Note that Core is _not_ a compatible, drop-in replacement for the standard library.  We've made different design decisions, and so code designed for the standard library would need to be adapted in order to use Core.

The Core suite has the following components:

* `Core`, which is the heart of the standard library
* `Core_extended`, a set of extra, less carefully tested and reviewed but still useful libraries.
* `Async`, a monadic concurrency library
* A set of syntax extensions, including `sexplib` and `bin_prot`, which extend the OCaml language itself.   These are _not_ necessary to use the rest of the libraries, but they are necessary for building them.

Core has been available for several years, but we've just moved to a new development model for our open-source libraries, and we hope this will make it easier to interact and accept patches from others.  We'll have new stable releases here soon, but for now, we just have the development tree hosted here.


## Download

Releases of Core are available here:

[https://ocaml.janestreet.com/ocaml-core/]()

## Interested in contributing to Core?

Great!  We're happy to work with people who want to help grow Core and the associated libraries.  In order to contribute to Core, though, you need to sign the Core CLA (Contributor License Agreement).  You can find more about the legal details [here](http://ocaml.janestreet.com/core-contributor-info.html).  And you can learn more about the practicalities of contributing
[here](ContributingToCore).

Core is available under the Apache open-source license.

## Resources

* Join the `Core` mailing list
  [here](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/ocaml-core).
* Read the [coding standards](CodingStandards) page to see the
  design principles behind `Core`.
* Read our [blog](http://ocaml.janestreet.com) to learn more about
  how we approach OCaml programming.
* The [DummiesGuideToAsync]().
* A set of [InstallationHints]().
* A [wish list](WishList).
* A guide for [ContributingToCore]().
* A [Helo World Project](https://bitbucket.org/yminsky/core-hello-world) to get you started on using Core
